OK. Here is my theory on schizophrenia., 15 years as a therapist in a state psychiatric hospital for violent patients. The 300 worst cases in the state. Not typical cases. Lot's of people with that diagnosis can live in the community with supervision. Schizophrenia is a brain problem. It's a birth defect. Neurology not psychology. Psychiatrists will all tell you it is inherited. I am a little different. I think it is present at birth but I think there is a big chance that it happens after conception. Something happens to the fetus in the second trimester. It may be a lack of folic acid. A weakness results that may or may not break out after birth. Stress has a lot to do with the first episode. Early adults, college, boot camp, etc. can cause a break. There may be a genetic predisposition to being sensitive to a lack of folic acid or whatever causes the problem in the second trimester. Big progress on medication. We were on the the third generation of pharma when I retired. The meds are very expensive. Private drug companies are sharks. Beds for schizophrenia are the number one most expensive line item in our hospital system.

I'm not saying that biology is irrelevant to understanding schizophrenia, just that there are whole load of other things going on on a social/cultural and probably all sorts of other levels that might actually be more relevant and useful to understand when it comes to helping people suffering from this condition (which I agree is not much fun for the person living with it, and at times can be really distressing beyond anything that most people will ever experience in their lives)

subtypes have since been removed from ICD-11 because subtypes are based on how schizophrenia primarily manifests in someone. Symptoms tend to change over time so this makes diagnosis ( of the subtypes ) unreliable. To fix this ICD-11 replaced the ‘subtypes’ with dimensional descriptors ie. positive ( presence of abnormal psychological activity such as hallucinations or delusions ) and negative ( the absence of what we consider to be normal such as avolition which is the inability to carry out goal oriented behaviours ) symptoms. this makes diagnosis far more reliable as doctors assess each symptom based on its severity at the time of consultation.

Why in juvenile detention?

@gaiagruel  Because a lot of kids in juvenile detention have mental health issues but are not diagnosed. They estimate that 1% of the population has schizophrenia. It would be difficult to find children that fit that criteria because current policy prohibits doctors from diagnosing kids with schizophrenia. There's a better chance of finding candidates for research studies in a facility like this. The prisons are full of people with mental health issues that may have started in childhood. ER records would be a second place to look for research subjects. Parents would have to sign permission to release medical records, and many parents who are having trouble with their kids would gladly sign up for that because they desperately need answers and help. Chances are these kids have more than one mental health problem. So if they have, say, Oppositional Defiant Disorder or Conduct Disorder, it may be worth delving deeper.

I was the biggest fan of Sapolsky until I listened to this drivel. I do have to sort out some of my feelings on the matter, it's true, but as someone who would certainly fit the DSM criteria for schizophrenia, but who favors a Jungian view of Schizophrenia as a process (which he referred to as "doing a schizophrenia"), I have to take issue with the view expressed that "schizophrenia has no hidden blessings." The only legitimate proof you need that this is an invalid statement is the word of a "suffering" schizophrenic who says, "Yeah, there are parts of this that I enjoy."  I appreciate the need to understand a disease objectively and that Sapolsky's priorities clearly lie along such pragmatic lines and I appreciate why the world needs people who look at things that way. However, the invalidating of the lived experience of the patient is where I am drawing the line here.  I don't care how "objectively" you can demonstrate that the schizophrenic's opinion about their disease is likely actually symptom of the disease; that is a moot point which doesn't do as much to discredit the perception as Sapolsky is (very arrogantly) concluding here. That lived experience is an important part of the equation.  When I hear people talk about schizophrenia in such start terms, I am reminded of a psychiatrist I once had who quickly put me on meds to bipolar disorder, and overmedicated a whole ward full of patients, then admitted on family night that he does what he does because he had a mentally ill brother.  I wonder if his mentally ill brother made it harder for him to pursue his academic goals? I wonder if the meds kept his brother nice and quiet, pliant, and out of the way?  I wonder: Do we over-pathologize conditions such as these because they are inconvenient to us and our priorities?  What other reason would we have for deciding that schizophrenics must simply be wrong about how THEY THEMSELVES FEEL? I think the people who really need help here are the friends and family of schizophrenics who are clueless about how to connect with the person they claim to love.  They should stop making this about the failure of the sick person.

I've dealt with a range of mental health issues in my life - mainly depression and anxiety to varying degrees but many others too like ADHD, OCD, PTSD, social phobias, eating disorders, substance abuse (it's been a journey). 3 years ago however, I had my worst psychotic break ever and experienced what paranoid schizophrenia is like first-hand. It was without a doubt the scariest and most mind-bending, world-altering thing I've ever gone through. Completely lost my grip on reality, totally deluded, thought everyone and everything was out to get me, believed l I was under government surveillance and that they were using "energy weapons" like microwave technology to read my thoughts and implant new thoughts into my mind, also believed I was demonically possessed and that evil spirits were tormenting me in my fallen state here on earth, I severely isolated myself and had thoughts of persecution 24/7 for months. It was living hell and I wouldn't wish it upon anyone. Totally lost myself and I still haven't fully recovered. The paranoid thoughts and delusions come back occasionally when I'm under a lot of stress and it's just completely changed my life. I'm much more cautious and reserved now, more conservative in almost every way, still very isolated and still don't think I have a strong grip on reality even though I'm "rational and coherent" now. I'm just lucky I had a loving and supportive family to fall back on when this happened to me because if I didn't, I'm sure I would either be homeless or would have done something radical to all the people who I thought were "government agents"... At 23:20 Prof. Sapolsky announces that he is skipping the depression lecture. And that he feels that ch. 14, STRESS & DEPRESSION, in the Zebras book "will tell all the same stuff in much better, more clear terms, I say proving my point. And what you should do is read it with as much attention to it as if it has been a lecture subject. It is an important subject. Enough hints. OK, so check that one out." It is obvious that the hint means that depression is going to figure in the exam. In fact depression is one of Prof. Sapolsky's favorite subjects. He did give a full lecture on it at another time, on Nov. 10, 2009, in the Stanford classroom. It lasts only 52' 28". He's also given other lectures on depression off campus, also recorded and available on YouTube. This proves a point I took pains to elaborate for his attention. That all the topics developed in each of the 18 chapters of the Zebras book are equally important, not just to Stanford students taking his course, but to the majority of common people trying to go through the daily challenges of life.The Zebras book brings modern neurological science to bear on the key parameters of biological and social existence: stress, as foremost, but of course. But also hormones, heart health, eating  and food, sex and babies, pain, memory, sleep, aging and death, and the immense role of psychology, the powers of depression and personality, the temptations of pleasure and addiction, the role of one's rank and place in society, and how to deal the best we can with all those challenges, pressures and other calamities of modern living. Many of us have bought the Zebras book, which still now is the 3d edition dating to 2004. We bought it in the hope to find in it a kind of guide to understand the baffling complexities of life and ways to better cope with them. To our innate tendency to live more at the level of rapid reactions to the emotions emerging from our limbic system, it adds the calming and reasoning dimension provided by the reflective knowledge and experience of a frontal cortex patiently informed by modern neurobiology . Since then, in the nearly 20 years of progress of neurobiology research, many questions left open in 2004 have received valuable clarifications and refinements. So the suggestion cannot be dismissed that it would be of tremendous value to all of us, ordinary people, if Prof. Sapolsky devoted some of his attention to revising and enlarging the Zebras book into a 4th edition, dated, say, 2024.  Prof. Sapolsky is now retired from active teaching, as a prof. emeritus. He has at his disposal a number of young graduate assistants who would be eager to assist him in assembling all the relevant new research as his documentation for this revision. And he is, naturally, the best placed to undertake this revised edition. The problem of course is, as in many challenges, personality. Our Incredibly Learned Professor has vast curiosity. He mentioned many times that he eventually realized that his youthful enthusiasm for stress, glucocorticoids, and the functions of the hippocampus and the amygdala has been succeeded during his mature years by a no less enthusiastic interest in the working of the frontal cortex,. This should have been his lifelong subject of research, had he only known better when he started off in his career as a scientist. In reality, the  constant, deep interest of Prof. Sapolsky — the one that drives so visibly through all the other books he's written before and after the Zebras book, and his sundry articles in scientific journals — has always been the impact on human behavior of the workings of the brain, in their positive and negative aspects. This encyclopedic inclination came to a complete expression in his monumental masterpiece BEHAVE, THE BIOLOGY OF HUMANS at OUR BEST and WORST. Having reached that intoxicating stage of global vision and wisdom, it may be less fun for the research enthusiast that Prof. Sapolsky still is towards the end of is career to revisit the topics of his younger age, when so much new, exciting stuff is happening all the time in brain research. However Prof. Sapolsky is at bottom — as is clear to whoever cares to read his previous books and pay attention to his comments in lectures — a wishful do-gooder, a scientist with a strong moralizing streak. Through his research, his lectures, his books, he hopes to have promoted an incentive towards the common good thanks to the enlightening impact of modern neuroscience. This is extremely clear from the topics ending the big book BEHAVE: the tendency of dividing people in US versus THEM, and its potential to generate conflict and wars; the complexities of rank and hierarchy, with their effects on mental balance and social consequences; defining the "right thing" to do if you can; etc. — all these themes expanding into vast reviews of morality, the role of empathy in human connections, the incredible power of language through its metaphors, the ambition to reform the criminal justice system, and so on. Prof. Sapolsky is flying high in those elevated subjects of Human Nature. His book wants to continue in the encyclopedic vein of Lucretius' DE NATURA RERUM, and Baron d'Holbach's SYSTEME DE LA NATURE. With this difference that Prof. Sapolsky sees the access to "Human Nature" through neuroscience and the workings of the brain. It's going to be pretty hard to bring Prof. Sapolsky back down to the narrower confines of the effects of Stress in everyday life, and the drudgery of revising the Zebras book. Still, there's hope if he should come to realize that his own effective contribution to the common good of the world in the concrete present is as well served, if not better, in giving us a refreshed version of his fundamental guide on Stress, as in his laudable high-flying reflections on the grand problems of society and mankind. ROO BOOKAROO, Nov. 9, 2022

Ok I can add another theory of why dopamine excess and schizophrenia go together:  Antiferroptotic activity of non-oxidative dopamine, 2016:  "Here, we show that the non-oxidative form of dopamine is a strong inhibitor of ferroptotic cell death."  In other words, since it is not a good idea for neurons to die, in the case of iron overload in the brain, the body would try to preserve the neurons by increasing dopamine, which at some point then triggers schizophrenia symptoms. Likewise, the lack of dopamine leading to parkinson's would follow from a a lack of protection against ferroptosis, and brain cell death is indeed what causes Parkinson's. It is also typical to find increased iron in the substantia nigra of deceased Parkinson's patients.  "Dopaminergic neurons are found in a 'harsh' region of the brain, the substantia nigra pars compacta, which is DA-rich and contains both redox available neuromelanin and a high iron content." Dopaminergic neurons, 2005  So not only is the substantia nigra the center of dopamine production in the brain, it also normally already has a high iron concentration, so it would be especially sensitive to iron induced cell death/ferroptosis.  Seems like a pretty solid hypothesis to me: iron excess deposition first manifests in substantia nigra, which responds with more dopamine to protect these essential neurons, which then leads to schizophrenia (which according to this talk is pretty ironclad tied to dopamine excess, given you can induce schizophrenia by too much dopamine).  Regarding the early onset of schizophrenia, it makes sense in the context of iron accumulation taking time (so it's not kids very often), while also one can imagine more iron being deposited during developing brain tissue, than after the brain is fully formed since there is very low cell turnover.  (Regarding the connection with viral stress and other infections, this is known to cause abnormally high iron deposition in the inflamed regions, if overall body/macrophage iron stores are too high)

Speaking of alternatives to dopamine to protect against ferroptosis: piracetam is known to improve aspiration and ATP production of mitochondria, and used in Alzheimer's. My mother is schizophrenic. You wouldn’t believe how many times my mother has been ostracized from family gatherings because someone in our extended family watched a movie that portrayed a schizophrenic individual as a demon possessed monster who would kill at any given time. Which is just so incredibly frustrating. They see a movie or show that portrays the schizophrenic as a loose cannon that could fly into a homicidal rage, and they suddenly remember “omg my aunt is schizophrenic, that’s what she’s going to do one day!”. It’s just wrong. My mother is very lucky because she has been on her medication for years without any episodes of chaos or mental trauma that were considered “bad”. She sometimes has trouble with listening to the radio or watching certain shows or movies, so she lives with me and we do a lot of gardening together and things that keep her busy and bring her happiness. My mother is a physically gorgeous woman with a beautiful heart, and she is my best friend. I try everyday to make sure she feels loved and happy, because she deserves it. Sadly, there are many people with schizophrenia who don’t have friends or family and that is heartbreaking.

Maybe if you’re a somewhat recent grad and you know all the ins and outs (like what doors will be open at what times; where to reliably find class offerings and schedules which may or may not be information available to the public depending on the school). Which is actually how most of the interesting classes are offered anyways.  And yeah, the keycard thing is huge these days. I was actually taking classes at Stanford back in 2017 and if you didn’t have a keycard, you were not going to have access to literally anything on that campus.  Oh, not to mention that all lecturers these days get tons of training on being able to spot non-students on campus and in their classrooms. If you don’t KNOW (like actually know) what/how students on that campus act and do, you’ll be viewed with suspicion. I’ve had professors call out “students” during class before... “Hey, what’s your name? I want to make sure you’re enrolled in this class.” Happened multiple times in some of my classes (pretty large classes too).   TL;DR: maybe that was true in the past;  but colleges are coming down on this pretty hard these days and it just really isn’t something people do anymore — for security reasons.

I'm so sorry people have treated your mother so poorly over their poor perception of symptoms of schizophrenia.  The understanding and empathy expressed towards folks diagnosed with this disorder is woefully lacking.  It is true that schizophrenics are rarely violent and the misperception that they are violent does harm to the person with the diagnosis as well as the family and community the person lives in.  My son is 22 and profoundly autistic with ADHD and tic disorder.  Unrelated to schizophrenia, but some similar symptoms and because he doesn't have functional language, people are often cruel or they misinterpret his thoughts, behaviors, and expressions.  I am so sorry you've experienced the stigma associated with a family member and someone you loved diagnosed with a mental health issue.  I teach abnormal psychology and clinical and counseling psych among other topics and I strive to educate folks about the diagnoses, but also developing compassion and sympathy for folks with any mental illness.  We are all a head injury, stroke, or traumatic experience away from developing a form of psychopathology.  We are far more accepting of anyone with a physical ailment than someone with a diagnosed mental illness.  The stigma surrounding an individual with a serious mental illness does violence to the very people experiencing it.  I wish you and your family peace and well-being.

My brother is also schizophrenic. I did years of research and found it's caused by an ATP7B copper binding gene defect, and it can be reversed by lowering the free copper level. The free copper test code at lab corp is 279071. It's not a normal serum copper test, but one that will measure the amount of toxic free copper in the blood. A fast and safe way to lower free copper is with allopurinol, a uric acid lowering drug. It also chelates copper. Google "allopurinol for schizophrenia" and there are alot of articles showing it works. Your mother also needs to take 50 mg pf zinc, one hour before meals, 3 times per day. The zinc will block copper absorption contained in food. She could add alopurinol to the meds she's already taking, then once the free copper is lowered in a few months to 6 months, her symptoms will go away, and she can start weaning off the anti psychotic meds. Good luck and God Bless.

@mellowyellow2022  This disease is one that completely destroys the individual suffering and their loved ones. It breaks my heart to think about you and the loss of your brother. As much as we don’t want to say it, love can only go so far. I live in solitude with my mother and my view of her symptoms are not unbiased. What I consider to be a “good day” or “bad day” is not something that can be appropriately described with only words. Compared to others, her day to day functioning and communication would be viewed on a different scale. I can only compare her symptoms and “episodes” to her previous ones. An outsider may think her good days are horrifying…but we all see things differently. What I see and live with has become our “normal”. It is not sunshine and roses by any means. But because we have tailored our life to fit her needs, and have more control on outside influences, we have created an existence that allows her to function as well as she can, factoring in her day to day distractions.   I know that molding my life into a safety net for her is probably not the best idea in the long run. Sometimes I think I’m a selfish daughter for catering my entire existence to fit her wants and needs…because I’m the one who it all rests upon. What kind of daughter am I really for building this glass bubble around us? What happens to her if I randomly get hit by a car or fall over dead one day? What happens to her when I’m not here to keep things the way they are? She will be at the mercy of this cruel world that has no regard for individuals who suffer from an all consuming mental illness like hers. Of course she’ll have money, she gets everything I have. But what if she can’t adjust and adapt? That is my worst fear.  But that’s the way life is. And to see her functioning as best she can, and see her as happy as an individual with her affliction can be, makes me keep going. She has schizophrenia…she’s not what the world sees as “normal”. She has horrific days, and terrible nights…but they are not as bad as they could be, because I do my best to shield her from anything that would make things worse. Medication, therapy, set schedules, outdoor activities, no outside influences that effect her negatively, immense patience, and love. That’s what keeps her going and that’s what I will do. I buried my son. And it killed me. And even though I may be selfish, I need her as much as she needs me.   I’m so sorry that you lost your child. There is no getting over that. No one should ever have to bury their child. Life is cruel and all we can do is max out the good times and live in the good moments. Because there’s no stopping the clock. Just an onward march into the future.

My brother was diagnosed with drug induced schizophrenia. I guess we thought of he stopped doing the drugs and alcohol the delusions would go away... And they do get better most of the time, but they don't go away, he's just not as paranoid, so maybe they're easier to manage for him. Anyway, his biggest delusion is that I am trying to kill him. He runs from state to state, because he believes so deeply that I'm trying to kill him. I live 1000 miles away from him now, don't know what state he's in, his number. I have tried to cut all ties with him. He's been on the streets the last 2 years, and he's recently asked my mother if he can move in with her. He misses family, and wants to be near his family. The thing is, I'm my mom's next door neighbor. He knows that. He's never believed he's having any delusions, he absolutely knows I'm living in his walls, following him on the streets, I've been in jail with him, I've gotten him fired from his jobs, I've put cameras in his house, these are things he absolutely believes, and is terrified that I'm going to kill him. He has admitted himself into psych wards, but he's out of there as soon as they mention he's probably schizophrenic. He won't seek medical care. Now I'm scared to have him living next door to my family. My biggest fear is he gets so paranoid that I'm trying to kill him, he comes and kills me one day.... My brother has never shown any signs of aggression towards me, he's scared of me. However, he does end up in fights with people on the streets, I know this because that's what he's usually put in jail for, fighting someone he works with, plays with, lives with, or does drugs with. I love my brother. I want a relationship with him, but I've given up because he's so out there. I don't want him to move next to us unless he's medicated and with a therapist or whatever type of doctor deals with this. Am I being irrational? I will admit I'm scared to live within waking distance of him. Maybe I'm wrong for that...🤷‍♀️ I love him, but his delusions seem to center around ME, and it's scary having someone hyperfocused on you.

I think what causes the fear in people is just that, the fear. The fear in non schizophrenic affected individuals being afraid of the affected doing something violent. It’s also the schizophrenic’s atypical behavior. Their behavior scares people and they end up ostracizing them. If they have delusions and hallucinations, that can be extremely jarring for people. It’s like people go into fight or flight mode. When they hear someone is seeing or hearing things that aren’t there, their reaction 99% of the time will be to run away. We do similar things to and have similar reactions to socially awkward people also. It isn’t right of course but it’s understandable. We may need more education for everyone to better understand mental illness and how to recognize it better. So we as a group can stop stigmatizing and instead learn how to handle it.

I've been diagnosed with schizophrenia

A few years ago I got really into working out and eventually ended up taking pre workout somewhat regularly. Little did my 16 year old self realize was that the pre-workouts I was taking were filled with many different types of amphetamines (legal but not fda approved obviously). After a year or so of taking straight pre workout I started to experience feelings of paranoia, anxiety, disassociation, and in the worst moments auditory hallucinations. I didn’t bring myself around others anymore and cut off most social contact because I was so lost in confusion. I felt like everyone could see what I was thinking like I was on the Truman show. Even after I stopped taking it and pouring dopamine into my brain I still experienced these symptoms for months. It seemed like I had changed my brain’s chemistry or really messed something up. To this day the anxiety and paranoia linger but are much more controllable. I am just grateful to not be in that space anymore. I feel like I got to experience a piece of what some people experience their entire lives. I empathize with anyone who has to live with such a hellish condition.
